author: Vijaita Singh
text:
The National Investigation Agency (NIA) will make another effort to determine the DNA profile of the two terrorists present at the Airmen’s Billet. Their charred remains were all that could be retrieved from the building, which was blown up by the National Security Guard (NSG) during the Pathankot operation.

There was a debate on the number of terrorists present at the airbase as only four bodies were found there. The charred remains collected from the billet were sent for forensic examination. The tests conducted at the Central Forensic Science Laboratory (CFSL), Chandigarh, concluded the “burnt mass material belonged to two men.” Officials had earlier said it was not possible “to establish the identity of the burnt male remains” as the “DNA could not be isolated.”

“We will be sending the samples again for determining the DNA profile,” said a senior official.

“If the forensic tests have established that the charred remains belonged to a male body, then determining the DNA should not be difficult,” a top forensic expert said.

Another expert, however, said that if there was “excessive charring”, then the sample cannot be amplified and DNA cannot be determined.

The DNA samples of the four other terrorists will be handed over to the investigation team from Pakistan, which will come to India on March 27.
title: NIA to have another shot at DNA profiling
